awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Digital Healthcare-Associated Infection: Measurement, Defense and Prevention in a Modern Digital Healthcare Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
The pace of digitization and interconnection of hospital systems has increased tremendously as recent healthcare legislation has encouraged the interoperation of medical record systems.  In addition to ordinary business operations data, hospital enterprise networks now carry patient record data and life-critical data streams from therapy systems (e.g., nuclear medicine, dialysis clinical systems). Unfortunately, the security implications of interconnecting such life-critical systems has been largely unstudied. This project is performing a large-scale analysis of the University of Florida Health System to detect the presence of malware and security weaknesses and determine whether security best-practices and techniques are sufficient to protect life-critical and privacy-sensitive medical systems.

While multiple recent studies have shown that individual medical devices are vulnerable to attack, none have assessed the current state of security at scale across medical organizations. This project is conducting a large-scale analysis of the current security posture of the University  of Florida Health System to inform a data-driven approach to vulnerability mitigation.  The researchers are first characterizing the security posture of the system through network-based measurements of malware presence (via Domain Name System (DNS) resolutions) and use of proper encryption practices (via inspection of X.509 certificates).  The project is next developing techniques to dynamically fingerprint and limit risky communications patterns and inject strong certificates into communication flows.  Finally, the project is developing techniques to predict devices at risk using algorithms that detect abnormal communication patterns via contact graphs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Modern medical systems are complex environments that rely on high interconnectivity with the larger Internet. With this connectivity comes a vastly increased attack surface, and security researchers have largely focused on the attack vectors that medical devices in these environments (e.g.,pacemakers and insulin pumps) face. However, to date, there has been no systematic, ecosystem-wide analysis of a modern healthcare system. This work investigates and measures the security of multiple aspects of modern interconnected medical systems, and characterizes the interplay with a variety of external parties. We demonstrate both places for improvement (e.g., traffic to malicious domains) and areas where such systems are better managed than traditional systems (e.g., replacing old ciphers).

Our work not only resulted in a large number of traditional academic papers, but also helped us to establish meaningful relationships to medically- related organizations, ranging from massive multi- campus healthcare systems to small community- run organizations focusing on domestic violence survivors. We have also become the first academic member of the Coalition Against Stalkerware, an international organization of ~50 organizations (e.g., tech companies, law enforcement, advocacy groups and academic partners) that is focused on identifying and countering applications that enable intimate partner violence, providing support for impacted individuals.

As such, this work has had significant academic and practical impact, helping to make make new methodologies to protect organizations and people.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2023
Modified by: Patrick G Traynor

Images (1 of )

    Hospital Network Architecture
  • Example of app camouflaging (indicated by red arrow).The icon of the emulated app Flash Keylogger appears similarto the default Android calculator app. At the time of analysis theapp was advertised as a �monitoring app for family members�. Ithas since been removed from the Google Play Store.
    Patrick Traynor
    Creative Commons
    Patrick G Traynor
    Application Hiding
